The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Thinking about type: what goes into building a graphic design composition and type itself.

A better understanding of how to integrate design elements and design oriented thinking towards the creation of a book, a poster, and a modular typeface (the three main projects in the class). Overall an increased appreciation for typesetting, typefaces, and typography and an overall increased exposure to graphic design. The course heavily uses InDesign with some Illustrator as well.
I learned about different typefaces, how to set type, how to make a book, and more.
A great overview of typographic principles, history, and experience with a variety of projects.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class is soooooo long. But otherwise, it's great. We spent most of our class time looking at our work and talking about it.

The course is a good first pass into typography, and covers a lot of breadth. One of the strong suits is the dissection of examples, and how Alice talks through her thought process when assessing how successful or not the piece is. I think the course struggled from the online format due to the length of the workshop (which drives home zoom-fatigue), and due to the fact that with 10 people, getting a thorough critique of all students work is hard. If the class size were reduced to 6-8 I think the class would benefit greatly.
A strength is the amount of feedback that was given from both instructors and peers. A weakness is that there wasn't too much formal instruction regarding how to use InDesign.
I would have appreciated a little more clarity with deadlines, as we were working on multiple projects at a time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how Alice adjusted our assignments to fit a more virtual format. For example, for the poster assignment, we designed posters that would fit an Instagram story and post. The chapbook assignment was quite hard to do virtually because we never got to look at the physical books in person.

Presenting work was quite successful, as much feedback was still given. Course organization through Notion was also great. One thing that could be improved is perhaps providing more workshops or tutorials regarding how to use InDesign.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if they were interested enough in the subject to be willing to put the work in.
Sure, if you like graphic design. I personally find graphic design to be soul-sucking, so I struggled, but if you have a healthy liking for arranging and shaping type, then you'll have a good time.

I think this course is definitely solid, but I would only really recommend this course to individuals who have taken Graphic Design and want to continue down that path, or who really love typography. There is a lot of material which is very important but not very flashy, and if you don't have a strong interest in type and typesetting beforehand, these discussions can feel a little bit dry. This is not the class to take to discover your passion; this is the class to take to purse it, and to take it to the next level.
I would recommend this course to students if they are interested in graphic design or type.
Yes! Alice is wonderful and the guest lectures were incredible. You learn so much from this course.
